stem: A 48-year-old client with Graves' disease received Radioactive Iodine (I-131) therapy 24 hours ago. He now presents with extreme tachycardia and agitation. Based on the documentation in the Nuclear Medicine & Endocrine Follow-up tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Acute thyrotoxicosis following radioiodine treatment.
Background: Severe hyperthyroidism. Refused surgery; opted for I-131.
Assessment: Heart rate is 154 bpm. Client is pacing the room, yelling, and appears 'scared for his life.'
Recommendation: Aggressive suppression of hormone effects.

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 172/94, HR 154, RR 30, T 104.4°F. Client is profoundly diaphoretic.

actionOptions.text: Administer IV Propranolol to decrease heart rate and T4 conversion
Apply cooling blankets and maintain a quiet, dark environment
Encourage the client to drink large amounts of water to flush the iodine
Administer Aspirin 650mg for the high fever

parameterOptions.text: Mental status and core temperature monitoring
Presence of a positive Babinski sign

rationale.correct: This is a Thyroid Storm (c2) triggered by radioactive iodine treatment. When I-131 destroys thyroid tissue, a massive amount of pre-formed thyroid hormone can be 'dumped' into the bloodstream simultaneously. Symptoms include severe fever, tachycardia (HR 154), and psychomotor agitation. The nurse should use beta-blockers (a1) to protect the heart and block peripheral hormone conversion, and cooling measures (a2) for the hyperpyrexia. Monitoring heart rhythm (p1) and temp/mental status (p2) is vital.
clinicalPearls: I-131 'Thyroiditis' or Storm usually happens within the first 7 days of treatment.
NEVER use Aspirin in thyroid storm because it displaces T4 from binding proteins, increasing free (active) hormone.
Propranolol is the beta-blocker of choice because it specifically inhibits T4-to-T3 conversion.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Radiation sickness usually involves N/V/D and bone marrow suppression. Extreme tachycardia and fever in a Graves' patient is always 'Storm' until proven otherwise.

mnemonic.title: Dump and Storm
mnemonic.expansion: Thyroid cells die. Hormones fly. Temp goes high. HR to the sky.
